Enter our essay contest honoring Joe Cook.

Joe Cook Memorial Essay Contest

How can schools better protect trans students’ rights?

Enter

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Earlier this year a federal court ruled in favor of ACLU client Gavin Grimm, finding that segregating transgender students from their peers violated their rights under Title IX of the Civil Rights Act and the 14th Amendment.

After a years-long court battle, it was an important moment of vindication for Gavin and trans students nationwide.

Here in Louisiana, we are committed to upholding the rights of all students, regardless of their gender identity, and making sure that everyone can learn in an environment that’s free from discrimination and harassment.

For this year’s Joe Cook Memorial Essay Contest, we are asking Louisiana high school seniors to reflect on transgender students’ rights. In what ways can cisgender students be allies for transgender students in school or otherwise? What kind of policies do you think your school should initiate to be more inclusive and welcoming of transgender students?

Joe Cook Memorial Essay Contest
Deadline: Wednesday, January 15, 2020
Prizes starting at $150!

The deadline for submissions is Wednesday, January 15, 2020, so please share this message with educators and parents in your community.

Alanah Odoms Hebert
Executive Director, ACLU of Louisiana
